The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school buildin.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly und.

I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. What Brother Aq

I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the su

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library while my m

I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library while my mother thought I was out playi

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library while my mother thought I was out playing stickball with the neighb

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library while my mother thought I was out torturing  with the neighborhood bullies.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time.

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me w

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me wanr to have those quakli

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will nevr forget one thing he said to me near teh end of th

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

---

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will nevr forget one thing he said to me near teh end of the summer, I had asked hi

I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will nevr forget one thing he said to me near teh end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought we woul

I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will never forget one thing he said to me near the end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought he would go to heaven. "I

I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will never forget one thing he said to me near the end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought he would go to heaven. "I wouldn't want to go to

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will never forget one thing he said to me near the end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought he would go to heaven. "I wouldn't want to go to heaven," he said, "un

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

The most important thing I learned in school was how to have empathy and compassion. And my first lesson was in the summer after fourth grade.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.

 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I was a lonely, bookish kid. I had very few friends and the summer stretched out before me, a relentless and boring juggernaut. I was a voracious reader, but I had read everything in the house. I biked over to my school building. It was Catholic school taught by brothers, nuns and priests. I was a little nervous about being there, but I thought I might be able to read in the library.
I walked into the library and was greeted by a t ray-haired, slightly stooped man name Brother Thomas Aquinas. He welcomed me in. He was a kind, gentle man, and seemed to instantly understand why I was there.

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will never forget o he said to me near the end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought he would go to heaven. "I wouldn't want to go to heaven," he said, "unless everyone I loved could be there with me."

What Are the Most Important Things Students Should Learn in School?

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will never forget something he said to me near the end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought he would go to heaven. "I wouldn't want to go to heaven," he said, "unless everyone I loved could be there with me."

That is

My father, an alcoholic, was seldom home and I had very little experience of a male parent. I had no idea what to expect from a father figure. That summer, Brother Aquinas gave me something I had been missing. He gave me a sense of what it was like to have a father.

We settles into an easy companionship, and I spent most of the summer in that library, while my mother thought I was out torturing insects with the neighborhood sociopaths.
Brother Aquinas was a great storyteller.
 He told me stories about the saints and the lives of the great philosophers. He told me about the great thinkers of the world, and about the great thinkers of our time. His empathy and compassion  toward me made me want to have those qualities too.

I will never forget something he said to me near the end of the summer, I had asked him if he thought he would go to heaven. "I wouldn't want to go to heaven," he said, "unless everyone I loved could be there with me."

That is true compassion.

In your opinion, what are the most important things students should learn in school? What is the most important thing you have learned in school? How has this knowledge affected your life? How do you think it will help your success in the future?
